ARTICLE.TITLE: Knives out for Freestyle Tout’s new ‘spend more’ ruling
ARTICLE.TEXT:
THERE has been a public backlash against a Brisbane restaurant’s move to ask all diners to order at least one meal per person.

Freestyle Tout owner Martin Duncan sparked the debate by saying too many patrons were sharing food and ordering tap water to drink.

He said that was making it difficult to pay his costs at Emporium in Fortitude Valley.

STOP SHARING: Time for you to give me my just desserts

One Freestyle Tout regular told The Courier-Mail she usually shared a dessert with her daughter because there was “far too much” sugar in them for her to eat it by herself.

“If this is how Freestyle wants to run the place, I won’t be supporting them,” the woman, who wanted only to be known as Linda, said.

Meanwhile, Brisbane’s restaurateurs have rallied.

Restaurant II executive chef David Pugh said he found some customers could occasionally “stretch the friendship” by ordering very little to share between a large group.

“As soon as you put a cloth down, we need $20 per table to cover our losses,” the Brisbane restaurant owner claimed.

Mr Pugh pointed the finger at university students as being some of the worst offenders.

“They’ll go in and want to split something – it’s all about catching up and splitting something, they’ll occupy seven seats and eat one piece of cake.”

Many cafe owners were also empathetic to Mr Duncan’s case – and all agreed some customers loitering after they finished dining was a problem – but none were willing to consider implementing a similar policy.

Pablo cafe owner Amy Bates said the key to dealing with patrons who overstayed their welcome was having good communication.

“At the end of the day, it’s called hospitality for a reason. And I think you’ve really got to extend that philosophy to your customers.”

media_camera The sticky date pudding which has been on the menu for more than 10 years. Picture: Tim Marsden

******************************************************

COMMENT: IT’S A MATTER OF MANNERS

PEOPLE will happily go to degustation-only restaurants at $150 a pop, or turn up to suburban Japanese restaurants with a $30 minimum spend, but a restaurateur asking that each patron purchase a dish during peak hour? Sacre bleu!

Restaurants aren’t a library, or a park. We don’t pay for them through taxes, they are someone’s business.

The tablecloths, hand-polished cutlery, water glasses and staff who hover to fill them up – all of those things come at a cost, before rent and electricity.

Restaurants operate on small profits. Being asked to respect the business is reasonable .

-Sharnee Rawson
